I don't really understand this:

This is a design decision t=
hat permeates JUnit, and when you decide to
report multiple failures per te=
st, you begin to fight against JUnit.

I don't see how having more that one=
 assert "fights against" JUnit (what
does this even mean?) and in the code =
that I see every day, very few tests
contain only one assert.  Especially i=
f your tests require two or three
statements to set up in the test method (=
not in setUp()), in which case
there is even more to be gained to run more =
than one assert so you don't
have to duplicate this code in other test meth=
ods.

Also, the fix you show in your documentation is simplistic.  What if =
the
code to be extracted is specific to that test method?  If you move it t=
o
setUp(), you are suddenly charging *all* the other test methods of that s=
ame
class with this set up cost that they have no need for.

Also, it seems=
 to me your recommended pattern for code that must throw an
exception ("don=
't catch it and declare the exception in the throws
statement") goes agains=
t common practice.  Plus, it will cause JUnit to
report an Error instead of=
 a Failure, although this distinction is
thankfully going away with JUnit4.=


A more common way to address this problem is to catch the exception and d=
o a
fail().

Other than that, your guide is fine advice.
